Abstract: Tensor network algorithms have emerged as powerful tools in computational physics, offering efficient methods for simulating quantum many-body systems. This review provides a comprehensive route map of tensor network algorithms, highlighting their applications in numerical simulations and quantum information theory. We discuss the fundamental concepts of entanglement and its role in these algorithms, emphasizing their ability to capture complex quantum correlations. The paper explores various tensor network representations, including matrix product states and projected entangled pair states, and their implementation in diverse physical systems. We also examine recent advancements in optimization techniques and their impact on algorithm efficiency. Finally, we address the challenges and future prospects of tensor network algorithms in advancing our understanding of quantum many-body physics and their potential applications in quantum computing and materials science.
